text: A quiet, deserted industrial street. It is over an hour b dawn and the street is still cloaked in the heavy stillne of night. In the weak light filtering out of their battered van, BE and CYBIL -- the Craft Service Managers, finish setting o breakfast supplies on a 6' table. They work in almost com silence, both nearly paralyzed with sleep. A cheap walkie talkie, lying beside a paper plate of soggy Oreos, sputte and buzzes occasionally. Other items on the table include mangled banana, seven grapes, and a box of chocolate cove donuts.
What time is it?
Four. Why?
This milk is bad.
(sniffs) When did you buy it?
Tuesday? I don't know. What's today?
Monday. (pause) There's a deli on Broadway.
Nothing closer?
Nothing that's open.
(sniffs the milk) Is it that bad?
I don't know. You're the one who  said it was bad.
At that moment a large truck grinds around the corner and shudders to a stop in front of the building. Bert replace the carton of milk neatly beside the orange juice.

Amid low, one-word greetings, the CREW tumbles out of the trucks and stands in a groggy cluster around the Craft Se table. WOLF -- the Cameraman, assumes a place of prominen He wears a black leather coat, a black beret, and black  leather half-fingered gloves.
This is the worst fucking coffee  I've had in my life.
Then don't drink it.
What're we doing today?
(pulls out a wrinkled  callsheet) "Interior. Living Room. Ellen talks  to Mom."
Any nudity?
Yeah, you have to take your fucking  pants off.
I'll do it. I like Ellen.
Yeah, she's a babe. She was the nurse  in that Richard Gere movie.
I worked on that.
The shower scene.
Start with the 5K in the window. Run  feeders for three blonds into the  living room.
Two people. Sitting? Standing?
Who fuckin' knows?
(walks off) "Ellen talks to Mom."

NICOLE sits quietly in the back seat of a beat-up station wagon. She glances out at the empty city moving past her  window and lets out a deep sigh. JEFF, the young intern assigned as her driver, glances in the rearview mirror.
Tired?
No, I've been up since four. I've  got a big scene today and I'm kind  of nervous.
"Ellen talks to Mom."
Have you read the script?
No. It's on the callsheet.
Oh. Well, it's pretty emotional. I  tell my mother I never felt she really  loved me.
You're going to yell at each other?
I don't know. I'm just going to go  with how I feel. Which is the scary  part. I'm very close to this  character.
Problems with your own mom?
Yes. But she died before I, well  before we could reconcile...
You were great in that Richard Gere  movie.
Thanks.

CU sidewalk. A pair of women's orthopedic shoes enter the frame and begin pacing. Camera pans up to reveal CORA, a small woman in her early 60s, pacing beneath the awning of her residential hotel. appears to be rehearsing dialogue with herself.
Ellen, I have no memory of this  whatsoever. Ellen... Ellen I have NO  memory of this whatsoever.
Jeff pulls the car up to the curb and Cora gets into the  back seat.
Good morning, "Mom."
(gruff) Morning.
Sleep well?
Not a wink.

Cora immediately lights a cigarette. Nicole instinctively wrinkles her nose and turns away. Cora notices this and m an exaggerated effort to keep the smoke away from Nicole blowing it hard out the side of her mouth. Jeff glances b at the two women in the rearview mirror. No one speaks.
NICK -- the Director, WOLF -- the Cameraman and WANDA -- AD, stand in a loose triangle on the darkened set. All ar holding coffee cups. The Gaffer can be seen in the backgr fumbling with a light.
Look, I'm not blaming anybody, Wanda.  I'm just saying we left last night  and I knew we didn't get that scene.
I'm sorry, I thought it was a great  scene, Nick.
It was OK; and it's going to be  alright. But I'm not settling for OK  today. This is a big scene and I'm  not leaving till we get it.
Whatever it takes, Nick. We're here  for you.
Alright, here's what I'm thinking.  Wolf, I want to do the whole scene  in one shot.
It's been done.
I know that but I'd like to try it  anyway.
Handheld.
No, dolly. We go from Close-up to  Wide-shot and back to Close-up in  the same shot.
I'll use the 35, minimize distortion;  I'll light it all from the ceiling.  It could be kind of great.
Sounds incredible. How long, Wolf?
I'll need to see a couple run- throughs.
Not too many. It's a tough scene for  the actors. I want them to feel  relaxed, fresh...
We've got all day, Nick. Whatever it  takes. What do you think, Wolf -- an  hour, 45?
I don't know how you drink that shit  black, Nick. I got to dump in the  milk. It's the only way I can cut  the taste.
Suddenly the Gaffer turns on the 5K, flooding the room wi harsh, blinding light.
Jesus!
What the fuck?!
Flame on, asshole!!
The screen goes completely WHITE.

Screen is still white. Gradually it shifts back to proper exposure revealing NICOLE in Medium CU. Her eyes are rive it is obvious she is emotionally primed for the scene. A  light meter is thrust in front of her face. She barely  registers it. WS, the entire Living Room set. Nicole sits on a sofa fac Cora seated opposite in an overstuffed chair. Two flats h been joined at right angles to create the Living Room cor A table lamp and assorted framed photographs complete the rather scrawny looking set. Most of the movie crew is seen, including Wolf looking th the camera.
OK, picture's up. Quiet. Stop the  work. Lock it up. Going for picture.
Nick approaches Nicole and Cora.
OK, nice and easy. Cora you're doing  fine. Remember, really listen and  really answer. (smiles at Nicole) I've got nothing to say to you. Just  let it happen. It's all there.
Ready, Nick?
Look at this a second, Nick.
Nick moves behind the camera and looks through the eyepie Another CU of Nicole fills the frame. The image is visual and emotionally breathtaking.
I pushed in a foot. She's incredible.  It's coming right through the lens.
Nick grips Wolf's shoulder in gratitude.
That's great, man. Beautiful.
Ready, Nick?
Let's go. Right away.
And, roll sound.
Speed!
And, roll camera!
Rolling!
Scene six, take one. (hits the sticks)
Action.

From the moment Nick calls "action" the film will cut dir to the shot the set camera is filming. The shot is fluid, graceful and in richly, beautiful COLOR. Nicole's perform is very strong; flawed only slightly by her nervousness.
Dad hit me first and knocked me down.  It didn't hurt that much but I started  crying anyway, hoping he would leave  me alone. He went over and started  hitting Danny.
Ellen, I have no memory of this  whatsoever.

You were just standing there looking  at me. Then you pulled me up and  said, "You're not hurt." Like I was  disgusting for faking, for doing the  only thing I could think of to keep  him from hitting me again.
I was worried about Danny.
You do remember.
He was smaller than you.
Nicole turns to Cora with the heartbreaking gaze of an  abandoned child. Nick and the rest of the crew watch in a
You were so worried about Danny --
Suddenly the BOOM dips all the way into the shot.
Cut! Boom in. Sorry, I had to cut.  Les, your boom was all the way in  the shot.
Well, where's the frame line?
All the crew move around, all talking at once.
OK, can we get a frame line? Hold it  down. We're going again right away.  Nobody moves. Les, you got the frame  line?
I guess so.
OK, here we go. Right away. Picture's  up.
Nick approaches Nicole and Cora.
Beautiful; both of you. Stay focused.  Stay with it. No big deal. Let's go,  Wanda. Right away.
Roll sound!
Speed!
Roll camera!
Rolling!
Scene six, take two. (hits the sticks)
And, action.
Dad hit me first and knocked me down.  It didn't hurt that much but I started  crying anyway, hoping he would leave  me alone. He went over and started  hitting Danny.
Ellen, I --
The image suddenly goes out of focus.
I'm sorry, I have to cut. I was  completely off on the focus. It's my  fault, I'm sorry.
Thanks for the apology but you'll  never work in this town again. (laughter)
I've got it now.
Here we go, right away. Lock it up.  And roll sound...
Speed!
Roll Camera!
Rolling!
Scene six, take three. (hits the sticks)
And, action.
The scene begins once again. Remarkably, Nicole's enormou commitment is just as full and sharp. Nick is in ecstasy.
Dad hit me first and knocked me down.  It didn't hurt that much but I started  crying anyway, hoping he would leave  me alone. He went over and started  hitting Danny.
Ellen, I have no memory of this  whatsoever.
Suddenly a car stops right outside, a heavy, bass-driven song blasting out of its trunk-mounted speakers.
Street noise!
That's a cut! (into her walkie) What the fuck's going on down there!?  You call that a lock-up!? Get that  car out of there!
Jesus Christ. Why doesn't the guy  just get a flatbed trailer with about  600 speakers on it and tow it behind  his car.

Everyone nods in annoyed agreement; everyone except the B man who appears to be following the music with the mike,  bopping to it through the headphones. Slowly, interminabl the music fades off into the distance.
And... it's clear.
(into her walkie) Do I have a lock-up?
kkkkkssst... sttttss yes.
Is that a real lock-up?
ssssssssssssppppkkss.
OK, right away. Picture's up. Roll  sound.
Speed!
And, roll camera!
Rolling!
Scene six, take four. (hits the sticks)
Action.
Dad hit me first and knocked me down.  It didn't hurt that much but I started  crying anyway, hoping he would leave  me alone. He went over and started  hitting Danny.
Ellen, I have no memory of this  whatsoever.
You were just standing there looking  at me. Then you pulled --
Suddenly the BOOM drops into frame again.
Boom's in.
Jesus Christ.
Where?
The whole left side of frame, Les.
Alright, can we please get a  motherfucking frame line please?!
The frame keeps changing.
That's the idea, Les.
May I make a suggestion? Is it  possible to maybe break the shot  down? Maybe two shots instead? Might  make it easier for Les.
No.
Then I need ten minutes to switch to  radio mikes.
Your call, Nick.
There won't be any other sound  problems?
No more boom problems.
Switch to radios.
That's a ten-minute break. Release  the lock-up. Stand by.
(to the AC) Get me a coffee. Half milk.

Nick looks for Nicole but sees only Cora standing by the  couch. Les has both arms up the back of her dress, runnin the wire to her radio mike. She's wearing stockings rolle down to just above her knees. Nick turns and spots Nicole by herself in a dark corner o the set and walks over to her.

location: SET APT. A CORNER. DAY. B/W

text: I'm sorry about all this, Nicole.
It's not your fault, Nick. Is there  a way to use some of the earlier  takes?
Not unless I change the shot; do a  cutaway of Cora or something and  intercut the takes. I don't want to  do that. It's a really nice shot and  what you're doing is incredible.
Thanks, Nick.
The radio mikes are going to make  everything easier. So, look. Take a  moment. Let all this shit go. We  don't roll till you're ready.
OK.
Nick moves back to the set, leaving Nicole in the shadows Camera stays on her as she begins emotionally preparing  herself once again.
How was she in that Richard Gere  movie?
So-so.

Camera slips halfway through an open bedroom door, holdin Nicole on one side of the frame while revealing PAM the S Supervisor and CYBIL sitting on the floor smoking. Though separated by the wall, Nicole hears everything the two wo say.
Her career really took off, didn't  it?
I saw her in a Michael Bolton video.
She is nice; but I could do a better  job.
Camera slips into a CU of Nicole. She closes her eyes as two women continue talking about her. Screen goes BLACK.
A BLACK scrim, held by the Gaffer, passes in front of the camera, revealing the set with Nicole and Cora settling i for a take.
Where's that flag going?
It's a scrim.
Wolf!
Two seconds, Wanda.
No. No more tweaking. Picture's up. (into her walkie) Lock it up!
Wolf quickly motions Gaffer to hand-hold the scrim in fro of the 5K.
And, roll sound.
Speed!
Roll camera!
Rolling!
Scene six, take five. (hits the sticks)
Action.
Once again the scene begins. Nicole shows the first signs losing her concentration.
Dad hit me first and knocked me down.  It didn't hurt that much but I started  crying anyway, hoping he would leave  me alone. He went over and started  hitting Danny.
Ellen, I have no memory --
Suddenly there is a tremendous EXPLOSION sending bits of  glass flying through the frame. Cora jumps, clutching her chest.
Oh, God!
CU the light the Gaffer had been holding the scrim before It is smoking and shattered.
Jesus fucking Christ!
(to the Gaffer) Kill it. Kill it. Pull the plug.  Right there by your foot.
That's a cut. Anybody hurt? Cora,  are you alright?
Cora nods wordlessly, gasping for breath.
Props. Props! Let's get a broom up  here right away. Clear the set!
Nick, Cora, and Nicole stand in a corner of the landing.  Nick is making obvious attempts to lighten the mood.
Well, let's see. What do you think  is going to happen next, Cora?
I'm going to have a heart attack!
No, you're not. You're going in there  in two minutes and we are really  going to nail this scene. I know it.  I have no doubt about it. Nicole...
Nick turns to Nicole and stops in midsentence. He looks a her for a long moment. Nicole returns his gaze then sudde looks away.
Nick! Nick!
One second!
Nick hesitates a moment then rushes back to the set.
I'll tell you this much right now; I  am never, ever doing another fucking  low-budget movie.
Nick joins Wanda and Wolf on the set couch and chair.
What's up?

Wolf and I were talking... Ellen's  losing it a little bit. You got three  quarters of the scene really, really  incredible in the first take. Do a  quick cut-away and all you need is a  pickup of the last part of the scene.
Wolf?
You know how I feel; I love this  shot. Hell, I designed it.
Then let's just stick with the game  plan, OK? It's a simple shot. We're  going to get it this time, I feel  it.
We're here for you, Nick. Whatever  it takes.
Nick moves off. Wanda stares at Wolf who studiously inspe his light meter.
Thanks.
Camera is close on the black-and-white clapboard. Nicole' face can be partially seen behind it.
And, roll sound.
Speed!
And, roll camera!
Rolling!
Scene six, take six. (hits the sticks)
Action.
As the scene begins again, it is obvious that both actres are completely distracted. Nick's face betrays a rapidly  increasing anxiety.
Dad hit me first and knocked me down.  It didn't hurt that much but I started  crying anyway, hoping he would leave  me alone. He went over and started  hitting Danny.
There is a long awkward pause as Cora realizes she can't  remember her line.
Cut. That's OK, Cora. What's the  line? Just say it to me; no acting.
I... (pause)
"Ellen, I have no memory of this  line whatsoever."
Amid general tittering from the crew, Wanda yells out.
OK, could we get the line please?!  Script!
(Pam) "Ellen, I have no memory of this  whatsoever."
Thank you. And, roll sound.
Speed!
And, roll camera!
Rolling!
Scene six, take seven. (hits the sticks)
Action.
The scene begins again. Nicole is lifeless; she's merely  saying the lines.
Dad hit me first and knocked me down.  It didn't hurt that much but I started  crying anyway --
I was worried about Danny!
Nicole stops cold, completely thrown by Cora jumping her  line.
I'm sorry, I'm lost...
Cut. It's OK. No big deal.
Nick's voice has the rigid tremble of someone barely able keep from screaming.
Everyone relax. We're just going to  run the lines. That's all. No acting.  Just run the lines. Then we're going  to shoot this fucking scene.

location: SET APT. THE COUCH. DAY. B/W

text: Nicole gets up quietly and sits next to Cora on the couch wordlessly taking her hand in hers.
(whispers) I'm so sorry. I'm fucking this up  for you.
(whispers) Cora, don't even think that. You're  doing great. I'm the one who's fucking  it up. If I get through this I swear  I'm never acting again.

She means it. Cora glances up at her, seeing for the firs time how pain and defeat have drawn the life from Nicole' face. On an impulse Cora reaches out and gently lifts a s of Nicole's hair from her eyes. A sudden amazed alarm fills Nicole. The living room grows strangely quiet.
(faintly, from a  distance) And, action on the run-through.
CU Nicole. She looks quickly toward Nick in confusion.

DISSOLVE to a nurse moving quickly past the camera and ou the open door of the hospital room. CU Nicole, seated on the edge of the hospital bed. Still  confused, she looks down at the old woman lying in the be The woman's face is pale and drawn. As Nicole leans close her mother reaches out and gently brushes a strand of hai away from her face. The gesture is one of love, acceptanc and farewell. It is identical to the one we have just see Cora make to her.
And action on the run-through.

WS, the Living Room Set. Nick, Wanda, the rest of the cre standing quietly. Nicole glances over at Cora and instant something unspoken and unexplained passes between them. T run-through begins. From the moment Nicole opens her mouth it is obvious ther has been a remarkable change in her. Every word now has t stunning clarity of truth. Cora is completely engulfed in the moment.
Dad hit me first and knocked me down.  It didn't hurt that much but I started  crying anyway, hoping he would leave  me alone. He went over and started  hitting Danny.
Ellen, I have no memory of this  whatsoever.
You were just standing there looking  at me.
As Nicole continues, one by one the crew turn and watch t exquisite moment happening before them. Nick's face is li with rapture.
(whispering) Roll camera... roll camera.
He glances over and to his horror sees that no one is beh the camera. He whispers frantically to the AC.
Where's Wolf?
(whispers) In the bathroom... he doesn't feel  good.
(whispers) Get him! Get him!
Nick turns back to the scene, watching its beauty now in  agony.
Then you pulled me up and said,  "You're not hurt." Like I was  disgusting for faking, for doing the  only thing I could think of to keep  him from hitting me again.
I was worried about Danny.
You do remember.
He was smaller than you.
You were so worried about Danny.  What about me, Mom? Why weren't you  worried about me?
There is a heavy, stunned silence as the scene ends. Nico and Cora are in each other's arms. Pam and Cybil share a  piece of tissue. CUT TO: an extreme CU of Nick.
Where the fuck is Wolf?!!!
In the cramped confines of the dingy basement bathroom, W pukes violently into the toilet. His face is pale and sli with perspiration. His eyes look upward toward the sound Nick yelling.
One second!
Wolf tries to continue but another spasm of nausea wrench him back toward the toilet bowl.

location: SET APT. THE COUCH. DAY. B/W

text: The set is quiet, subdued. Nick sits on the couch with Ni and Cora. Wolf sits groggily behind the camera wiping the sweat from his face. Wanda addresses the crew.
OK, listen up. Nobody drinks the  milk downstairs. OK? It appears to  be bad.
Nick speaks uneasily to Nicole and Cora. He is a wreck an his insistent smile of encouragement looks absolutely  demented.

I've had to, well I've changed the  shot; we're just a little pressed  for time. It'll just be a CU of Ellen  for the last part of the scene,  starting with Cora's "I was worried  about Danny." OK? I'll find a way to  cut this into the fourth take. We  almost had it. That was unbelievable,  both of you. But let's not think  about it. That moment is gone, and...  we'll, we'll get another one. I have  no doubt about it. OK? Here we go.
Nick walks over and stands beside the camera.

location: SET APT. BY THE CAMERA. DAY. B/W

text: I'm ready, Nick.
Nick is so angry he can't even look at Wolf.
Call it, Wanda.
And, roll sound.
Speed!
And, roll camera!
Rolling!
Scene six, Pickup, take one. (hits the sticks)
Action.
The scene begins at the pickup point. Miraculously, both  Cora and Nicole are just as concentrated and engaged as t were in the run-through.
I was worried about Danny.
You do remember.
He was smaller than you.
You were so worried about Danny.  What about me, Mom? Why weren't --
In the middle of this final, delicate moment an insistent electronic beeping is heard.
CUT!!!!
What the fuck is that?! Sound?
(frantically checking  his equipment) It's not me.
It's the camera.
The fuck it is. It's off; it's not  even running.
The beep continues, growing louder.
(into her walkie) What's going on down there?! Do I  have a lock-up?! Nothing? You don't  hear a beeping sound? (to Nick) The street's quiet.
Then what the fuck is it!!?
It's somebody's watch!
Everybody holds their watches up to their ears.
Not mine.
Not mine.
Not mine.
Not mine.

And so on, until all watches have been checked with negat results. The beeping continues, growing louder and louder Suddenly Nick loses it. He starts running around the set, ripping things apart, knocking over tables, lamps, chairs He shoves Cora off the couch and whips off the cushions,  heaving them against the wall with a startling violence.
Where is it!! You motherfucker! You  cock-sucking motherfucking bastard!  Where the fuck are you!? Where!!  Where!!
Everyone watches Nick demolish the set in stunned, open- mouthed amazement. Nick turns to the crew in rage.
Can someone help me please?! Do I  have to do everything myself here?!
Nick loses it completely.

Hey, Cora. Why don't you go learn  your lines! Hey Scriptgirl, are you  finally going to pay attention here?!  Hey, focus puller, you want to make  a movie or get stoned?! Huh, I got  some great fuckin' Thai Stick here!  Hey Wolf, you pretentious, beret- wearing motherfucker! I saw your  reel, man; it sucked! Who the hell  would hire you anyway! Hey Wanda,  next time can you wear a shirt that's  a little more distracting to my  actors! (to the Gaffer) Hey Bob! Hi Bob! Can you please make  a little more noise on the dolly you  creaky motherfucker! (to Cybil) What is your name!? What do you  fucking do around here?! (to the Soundman) Hey Speedo, what's the matter? Can't  even find a teeny fucking beep?!
CU of Nicole. She turns away, unable to watch anymore. Th beeping continues.
See what I have to put up with,  Nicole!? Maybe next time you'll do  some of that magic on camera!? But  no, no -- wait till Wolf is puking  his guts out, "Oh now I'll be good!!"
WS, the entire room. Nick's last word echoes throughout t silent set. Suddenly he stops in the center of the demoli set and lets out a long, wrenching scream.

QUICK CUT TO extreme CU Nick's face, just as his eyes ope The film is in COLOR now. The room is in heavy darkness e for the light on Nick's face. Nick reaches over and shuts off his clock radio. The digital dial shows 4:00 A.M. The beeping finally stops. Nick turns on a light and sits up in bed, drenched in swe and still breathing heavily.
God... (this is not a sigh  of relief)

The camera DOLLIES swiftly back away from Nick. He stares it in stunned amazement. Just then a DOOR closes right in the lens turning the frame into complete BLACKNESS. Out of the BLACKNESS a door opens away from the camera  revealing WANDA looking into her closet (the camera is in the closet). From this point on, the rest of the film is COLOR except where specifically indicated to be Black and White.

She is wearing only a bra, black stretch pants, and cowbo boots. She rummages quickly through some blouses, selects the same garish one she wore in Part One, then walks away revealing WOLF sitting on the edge of the rumpled bed. He dressed exactly the same as when we last saw him, complet with beret. He struggles groggily into his socks and boot The entire apartment is in disarray. A bedside clock read 4:13 A.M.
Well, when did he ask you?
Yesterday, when I was helping him  check into his hotel.
What, the guy can't even check into  a hotel by himself?
Listen, Wolf, having Chad Palomino  in this movie will benefit us all.  If being there when he checks into  his hotel makes him feel better,  then I'm happy to do it.
Well, how did it come up?
He asked me if I liked jazz, I said  yes, and he suggested we meet tonight  at a jazz club.
I like jazz.
He did not invite you. (applies perfume)
Why are you wearing perfume to work?
Because I feel like it.
You didn't wear it yesterday.
Oh, stop it. You're acting like a  child.
Wanda playfully swipes at Wolf's face with a negligee she returning to the closet. It misses him completely.
My eye!
Oh, God. Sweetheart, are you alright?
Do I look alright?!
Let me see. Christ, we're going to  be late.
Wanda sits and perfunctorily examines Wolf's eye.
The car is parked outside a rather seedy hotel. JEFF, the Intern and NICK, the Director, sit quietly in the motionl car.
Should we call up to the room again?
He said he'd be right down.
Nick lets out a huge yawn.
Tired?
I'm exhausted. I dreamt I was on the  set all night. I was just trying to  do one shot and everything kept going  wrong.
That's an anxiety dream. Are you  anxious about something?
I don't know. Sometimes I wonder  what the hell I'm doing in this  business. It's all just one compromise  and disappointment after another. I  don't know if I have the personality  for it.
Sounds kind of like an identity  crisis.
Maybe you're right. Who am I? What  am I really capable of? Maybe I should  just get a job teaching at a women's  college somewhere.
How'd you get into cinematography?
I'm not a cinematographer.
You're not?
No. I'm directing this movie.
(pause) How'd you get into directing?

In the dim light of the hotel room, CHAD PALOMINO dresses quickly. He is young, handsome, with long blond hair. A W sits nude on the bed, her back to the camera. The faint s of a shower comes from the adjacent bathroom.
They're waiting downstairs.
Go ahead, I'll take a taxi.
Oh, OK. Listen, I've got to tell  you, I had a lot of fun last night,  really, but for me, where I'm at  right now in my life, a relationship  is...
Chad; hold it. This was a one-time  deal. You know it, I know it. There  is no need for melodrama.
I just thought you might...
Look, all I ask is that you don't  mention this to anyone.
Hey, that's not my style.
Good.
So, I'll see you on the set.
Palomino slips out the door. The woman falls back onto th bed, turning her face toward the camera. We see it is NIC
God damn it.
She lies for a moment, listening to the sound of the show The bedside clock reads 4:30 A.M.
The car pulls up outside a NYC apt building. Jeff, Nick, Palomino sit inside.
I got two films coming up right after  yours, Nick. One I play a rapist  that Michelle Pfeiffer falls in love  with. The other I'm kind of a sexy  serial killer who shacks up with  Winona Ryder.
That's great, man.
Yeah, but I'm not into that hostess  twinkie shit, Nick.
Hostess twinkie?
That Hollywood shit. It's all fluff,  man. These are the kind of movies I  want to do, right here.
I'm glad you feel that way, Chad.  And I just want to tell you, I'm  really happy we can work together.
Hey, me too! You're a great director,  man. Your films are wacked! And I'm  gonna be watching you, buddy. Like a  hawk. I want to learn from you, Nick.  I'm gonna pick your brain.
Good. Then you can pick my nose.
(big laugh) See what I mean? You're wacked. Hey,  what are we sitting here for?
We're waiting for Nicole.
Nicole? She's takin' a tax -- (he stops)
What?
Probably taking a shower or something.  Hey, how was her shower scene in  that Richard Gere movie?
Good.
Really great.
The three men sit in silence. WS, showing the car parked  outside Nicole's apt, the men inside waiting.

A small, elegant bedroom set has been constructed in the  middle of the huge empty space. One wall has a fake windo The GAFFER lies on the bed staring absently at the AC sit motionless beside the camera a few feet away. Neither spe for a long moment.
I think we got nudity today.
(reads from his  callsheet) It just says "Scene Six: Ellen and  Damian kiss."
Could be a kiss with nudity.
I like Ellen. She's my type.
Why is that?
She's pretty. Smart. Kind of kooky.
Maybe I'll give her a part. That's  right; I'm makin' my own movie pretty  soon.
Oh yeah?
Yup. Feature. I brought my script.
The Gaffer tugs a thin, tattered SCRIPT, folded lengthwis out of his back pocket.
Palomino's perfect for the lead. I'm  going to give it to him right during  lunch. Maybe right after.
Alright.
Got to be aggressive. You want to  shoot it?
Sure.
You ever shot anything?
No.
That's alright; got to start  somewhere.
Suddenly the Gaffer reaches out and warmly shakes the AC' hand.
Nicole sits before the makeup mirror. LORDE, the male Mak artist picks up a tube of Preparation H and begins applyi it under Nicole's eyes just as Nick walks up.
Jesus, what are you doing?
Shrinking tissue. That's what this  stuff is for. Let that sit for two  minutes, pumpkin; I'll be right back.
How'd you get here?
Took a taxi.
Oh. We've been waiting in front of  your apartment for half an hour.
God, I'm sorry, Nick. Something came  up. I forgot to call. I'm sorry, I  feel like such an asshole.
You're just saying that because you  have Preparation H on your face.
I never should have gone out last  night. I hate jazz. God, I look  terrible.
No you don't.
Don't bullshit me, Nick.
I'm not. You really look beautiful.
Something in Nick's voice makes Nicole glance up at him. looks away quickly. The moment is awkward, as if they bot realize he has inadvertently revealed something. Just the Palomino approaches.
Hey! How'd you get here, Nicole?
I took a cab.
Oh, cause we were wondering how you  got here.
Nick looks at both of them in a moment of silence.
Alright, good; everybody's here.  We'll do a run-through as soon as  you guys are ready.
You got it, Chief.
Lorde reenters as Nick leaves. Palomino sits in the chair beside Nicole and Lorde immediately begins his makeup. No one speaks.

The crew is assembled behind the camera. Wolf is now wear a black eyepatch over one eye. Nick is on the set, talkin with Nicole and Palomino. Palomino wears a tuxedo and Nic is in an elaborate low-cut gown.
Hold it down, hold it down, people.  Actors working.
Great shirt, Wanda.
(big smile) Why, thank you, Chad.
OK, let's work out the rest of this  blocking. Wolf -- (notices Wolf's  eyepatch) What happened to your eye?
A little accident.
You going to be alright?
I think so.
It looks good on you, man.
Nicole is standing here, Chad, you're  there by the chair. Camera is close  on Ellen: her first line.
I've always admired you from afar.
Admired? That sounds rather  professional.
Good! "Professional," that's the  cue; Damian steps up to the bed.  Camera pulls back. The scene  continues.
Well, then: loved. How does that  sound?
It sounds like the champagne talking.
I've loved you from the moment we  met.
Why didn't you tell me?
We were working together. I didn't  want anything to interfere.
God. And all this time I thought...
Then the kiss. How's that feel?
Great.
Nicole?
Good.
Wolf, any thoughts?
Nope.
I've got a thought. What about Damian  having an eyepatch like Wolf's?
Let me think about that one, Chad.
OK, you're the genius. Nick Reve,  Living in Oblivion, Scene Six, Take  One. Let's shoot it!
One second, Chad. You ready for one,  Wolf?
Hell, I been ready.
Alright, Wolfman.
Good. Call it, Wanda.
Going for picture. Lock it up. And  roll sound.
Speed!
Roll camera!
Rolling!
Scene six, take one!
And, action.
Instantly the film cuts from color to B/W. Chad and Nicol begin their Love Scene.
I've always admired you from afar.
Admired? That sounds rather  professional.
The camera starts to dolly, however Chad does not move. H goes out of frame forcing Wolf to pan abruptly to Nicole.
Well, then: loved. How does that  sound?
It sounds like the champagne talking.
I've loved you from the moment we  met.
(finally moves to his  mark) Why didn't you tell me?
We were working together. I didn't  want anything to interfere.
God. And all this time I thought...
Palomino and Nicole embrace. Their kiss, like the entire  scene, is flat, lifeless, and awful.
Cut. Very good.
Not for camera. Chad was completely  out of frame.
Yeah, Chad; what happened, buddy?  Forget your cue?
Oh no, man. I held back. It really  felt like something Damian would do;  holding back to the last moment.
Oh, I see. How's that for you, Wolf?
I don't care when he moves. Just  give me a fucking cue.
The Lone Wolf!
What line did he move on?
"Why didn't you tell me?"
Alright, "me" is the new cue. Nicole,  how does that feel to you?
Fine, if that's what Chad wants to  do.
"Me, me, me," that's the cue. Let's  shoot; I'm stoked!
One second, Chad.
Nick approaches the bed and speaks quietly to Chad and Ni
Chad, how would you describe this  scene, in one word?
Great. It's a great scene, man.
No, I mean it's a love scene. Right?
Definitely.
These two people really love each  other. And we want to see that,  especially in the kiss.
Hey, say no more, Chief.
Nicole?
I understand, Chief.
Good. Here we go. Call it, Wanda.
Going for picture. Lock it up. And  roll sound.
Speed!
Roll camera!
Rolling!
Scene six, take two!
And, action.

head_text.subj: INT. THE SCENE. TAKE TWO. DAY

text: I've always admired you from afar.
Palomino moves immediately to the bed, changing his block and causing the camera crew and Nicole considerable confu
Admired? That sounds rather  professional.
Well, then: loved. How does that  sound?
It sounds like the champagne talking.
I've loved you from the moment we  met.
Why didn't you tell me?
We were working together. I didn't  want anything to interfere.
God. And all this time I thought...
The scene once again is awful. Nick gives their listless  kiss a few moments then calls CUT.
And, cut. Very good. Wolf?
Chad missed his cue again; the whole  dolly is unusable.
Yeah, Chad. What happened; I thought  you were going to hold back till  "me"?

The more I thought about it the more  it didn't seem right. And I'm  thinking, watch me here, instead of  coming around the bed, what if I  just slip here like this and do the  whole scene lying down?
I don't know, that seems a little...
Hey, I'm just throwing out ideas  here. Trying to get the juices  flowing.
Nicole, how does that feel to you?
Well, I can turn to look at him. But  won't you be shooting the back of my  head?
Plus Chad is completely out of the  light down there.
Hey, Wolf; I'm not worried about my  face, man. It's about the acting;  that's all I care about.
It's your call, Nick. His acting or  his face.
For some reason I was hoping we could  get both. (laughs) I thought that's what we were trying  to do here.
I'll have to set another light.
We're ahead of schedule, Nick. I  think we can afford a few minutes to  set a light for Mr. Palomino.
Good, let's do it. Ellen, Damian;  let's talk for a second.
As Nick, Nicole, and Palomino step off the set Wanda spea to the crew in general.
We'll pause to set this light and go  again right away. How long, Wolf?
Wolf doesn't answer, though he stands a mere foot away,  watching the Gaffer set up a light.
Wolf?
Wolf walks away from Wanda without a word. The entire cre watches this.
Nick, Palomino, and Nicole confer, all three smoking.

OK, let's make sure we know what's  going on here. These two people have  loved each other for years, each of  them not knowing the other was in  love with them. And tonight, in this  little room it all comes out. It's  like a dam bursting. Does that make  sense? Nicole?
It makes perfect sense. I just haven't  found it yet. I'll get it though.
What about you, Chad?
I'm there, man. I got the dam going,  the river, everything. You watch,  that little change in the blocking  is going to open the whole scene up  for me.
We're ready, Nick!
Good. Let's go.
Going for picture. Lock it up. And  roll sound.
Speed!
Roll camera!
Rolling!
Scene six, take three!
And, action.

head_text.subj: INT. THE SCENE. TAKE THREE. DAY

text: I've always admired you from afar.
Palomino saunters over and sprawls on the bed, forcing Ni to turn her head completely away from the camera.
Admired? That sounds rather  professional.
Well, then: loved. How does that  sound?
It sounds like the champagne talking.
I've loved you from the moment we  met.
Why didn't you tell me?
We were working together -- I'm sorry,  can we cut, Nick?
Cut!
That's a cut!
Dammit! That was a good one!
I know, I'm sorry. But this feels  really awkward; turning all the way  around like this.
Yeah, I think the lying on the bed  is not quite working, Chad. Let's  try one with the original blocking.
Which one was that? There's been so  many damn changes. Could somebody  help me out please?
The cue for the original blocking is  "professional."
(intimate) Thank you. Thank you very much.
OK, right away. Call it, Wanda.
Nick? Could I just have a moment? Is  that alright?
Of course, Nicole; are you kidding?  Hold the roll, Wanda.
Holding the roll!
Nicole remains seated on the bed, lowering her head and  closing her eyes as she attempts to generate some emotion for the scene. Everyone watches her in complete silence.

Palomino tiptoes over to the camera where Wanda and the  Scriptgirl are standing side by side. As he leans between them, checking his lines on the Scriptgirl's script, he  inhales deeply then exhales with a barely audible sigh.
(whispers) Someone over here smells very, very  nice.
Thinking he means her, Wanda's lips flutter in a brief,  involuntary smile. Meanwhile, the Scriptgirl turns away,  blushing furiously.
Palomino tiptoes again back to his spot. Nicole raises he head and nods once to Nick. She seems to have aroused som real emotion in herself.
(with quiet intensity) Call it, Wanda.
And roll sound.
Speed!
Roll camera!
Rolling!
Scene six, take four!
(suddenly) Nick, I just had a great idea!
Hold the roll!
What is it, Chad?

Just stop me if I'm out of line here,  but she says "admired from afar,"  right? Doesn't it make sense to see  Damian up close and her "afar?" You  start on a Close-up of Damian, watch  me here; as she declares her love,  the camera moves with me into this  primo two-shot that you and the  Wolfmeister have set up here.
What do you think, Wolf?
I don't like it. This is Ellen's  scene.
I don't know; it sort of makes sense.
Hey, you did it, man. It's all there  in the writing.
I'd have to relight.
Nick pauses, thinking hard.
We're still ahead of schedule, Nick;  if that means anything to you.
Let's do it.
(to the Gaffer) Get me a tweenie right here, with  diffusion.
OK, everyone stand by. We're pausing  briefly to set one little light,  then we're going again, right away.  Stand-in please for Mr. Palomino.
I'll do it.
Get the fucking light!

Several members of the crew loiter around the table. The  Scriptgirl approaches carrying a donut in one hand and a of coffee in the other. Palomino notices her and moves qu to her side. Without a word he picks up the milk and pour some in her coffee. Nicole stands nearby and watches the  following exchange.
Thanks.
My pleasure. Sugar?
Just a bit.
Palomino puts sugar in her coffee with extreme care.
You like jazz?
Very much.
Maybe we could go hear some tonight.
Palomino smiles and moves away just as Wanda comes up for coffee refill.
It's going well I think. Don't you  think?
Very well. What time do you think  we'll finish?
Early I hope. I'm going to a jazz  club tonight.
Really? So am I. He's wonderful,  isn't he?
Chad?
He's so natural, like... air.
Nicole approaches.
I wonder what his sign is. Do you  know, Nicole?
I don't know his sign, but I think  his moon is in Uranus.
Wanda chokes hard on her coffee as Nicole walks off with bitter smile.
You don't have to be nasty.
Palomino saunters onto the set as Wolf and his crew finis relighting.
Yo, Wolfman. Is this my new mark?
Until you change it. Where's my  fucking eyepatch?!
Wolf walks off. The Gaffer slips the AC a shrewd wink the walks over and stands next to Palomino, giving him a big, friendly grin.
Hey, Chad.
Hey, whatya say.
I'm Bob. I'm lighting this show.
Chad Palomino; Actor.
(big smile) I know.
(to the ac) Hey, what's your name?
Maurice.
Maurice! Hey, Maurice Chevalier! Any  relation? Probably not. Hey, smoking  crew guys, really.
The Gaffer slips his own script out of his back pocket an begins leafing through it.
Hey thanks, Chad. Actually I wrote a  script.
Oh, yeah?
Palomino takes the Gaffer's script and holds it up to his eyes, shading them from a light he's looking at across th room. He points to the light.
Hey, Bill. See that light over there?
Uh, yeah.
Lower it about three feet.
Palomino hands the Gaffer back his script and walks off. Gaffer and AC stand in silence for a long awkward moment.
Nick intently scrutinizes himself in the mirror. Leaning  closer he makes a careful adjustment to the way his hair  falls over his ear, then steps back to examine himself.
Would you care to have a drink  tonight? Hey, Nicole, what do you  say you and I have a drink tonight?
Suddenly the door opens behind him and Nicole walks in.
Oh, Nick! I'm sorry!
That's OK, no problem. I'm just  slapping a little water on my face.
The two stand in embarrassed silence for a moment. Nick l like he's gathering the nerve to ask her out.
So, it's going pretty good, huh?
Is it? Something feels off.
Yeah, you seem a little tense.
Do I?
But don't worry about it. Just take  your attention off yourself and put  it on Chad. Work off him a little  more.
OK, I'll try that.
And listen, I know he's no Olivier.  But he's got something, don't you  think? Kind of a natural presence.
Oh yes, he's very natural.
Nick hesitates, again gathering his nerves to pop the  question.
So Nicole... anything else I can  help you with?
Actually there is. Could you maybe  ask him to brush his teeth?
Oh, sure.
Wanda crosses the set and assumes her position beside the camera. Wolf sits behind it, barely a foot away.
My eye is killing me.
Put your eyepatch on.
I lost it.
Is that little light set yet?
That little light was set ten minutes  ago.
(into her walkie) Get me the A Team in here right away.  Nick, Nicole, and Mr. Palomino. (to Wolf) Why didn't you tell me?
Hey, you're not worried about the  time, I'm not worried about the time.
Oh, I am very worried about the time!
I know you are.
What is that supposed to mean?
What do you think it means?!
I don't know what it means!
Oh yes you do, you know exactly what  it means.
I have no idea what you're talking  about! Why are you --
You don't understand me, Wanda! You  have no idea --
I don't understand you?!! All I do  is take care of you!!!
Nick suddenly runs up just as Wolf and Wanda are on the v of blows.

Hey, hey, hey! What the hell's going  on here?! Jesus, Wanda. This is a  very intimate scene and a lot of  tension on the set doesn't help. OK?  Now, Wolf, let's just go through the  first part of the move. Damian, on  your new mark. Good. Close-up, Damian;  Ellen in the background.
Nick suddenly sees Palomino is wearing a black eyepatch.
Chad, what are you doing?
Hey, that's my fucking eyepatch.
Wolf, could I borrow it? Cause I'm  telling you, Nick; it really feels  right. I feel like this guy now,  man.
I don't know, Chad. I don't think it  works.
You're wrong, man. I'm going to fight  you on this one.
Hey, it's my fucking eyepatch and I  don't want anyone wearing it. It's  insanitary.
Palomino removes the eyepatch and tosses it back to Wolf.
Fine. I'll get my own. Nick, send  someone out for an eyepatch. I'll  fucking pay for it myself.
Nick pulls Palomino aside and whispers to him confidentia
Listen, Chad. I didn't want to say  this in front of Wolf but it makes  you look a little... gay.
Really?
Yeah, a little bit.
Jesus.
Palomino sneaks a glance back at Wolf then whispers to Ni
You're right. Thanks, buddy. Good  call.
Are you ready, Nick?
One second. You need a rehearsal,  Wolf?
Let's just fucking shoot it!!
El Lobo!
Palomino winks at Nick and walks back to his new mark, ma a barely audible howling sound behind his hand.
Call it, Wanda.
Going for picture. Lock it up. And  roll sound.
Speed!
Roll camera!
Rolling!
Scene six, take four!
And, action.
The scene begins again. Palomino milks his Close-up for a it's worth.
I've always admired you from afar.
Admired? That sounds rather  professional.
Well, then: loved. How does that  sound?
Right on his cue, Palomino walks to the bed. As the camer moves into the 2-shot he begins stroking Nicole's hair wi extreme care and concentration.
It sounds like the champagne talking.
I've loved you from the moment we  met.
Why didn't you tell me?
We were working together. I didn't  want anything to interfere -- God!
Under the onslaught of escalating hair-stroking, Nicole  suddenly jerks her head away hard. Palomino jumps up and  begins pacing at the rear of the set.
Cut!
That's a cut. Hold the work, going  again, right away.
I'm sorry, Nick. I don't know why I  did that. I'm sorry.
Palomino suddenly stops pacing and addresses Nick with a  curtness that is a little startling.
Nick, could I talk to you a second?
Palomino disappears behind the set, a jerk of his head  indicating his wish for Nick to follow him.
A momentary delay. Everyone stand  by. We're going again, right away.
Excuse me, Ellen? You were a tad low  on that take.
Oh, OK. I'll bring it up. Actually  could I listen to the take before?
The Sound man gives Nicole his headphones and rewinds the tape recorder for her. The first several lines of the las take are heard through the headphones.
Nick follows Palomino behind the set, stopping just besid the fake set window. Palomino whirls on Nick and whispers fiercely.
I'm out of here, man!
What's the matter?!
I like you, but I made a big mistake  taking this part. Have someone call  me a cab.
Wait a second, Chad. Just talk to  me. What's going on!?

I can't act with this woman. I know  she's a friend of yours but I got to  tell you: she cannot act worth a  shit! I'm giving her everything! The  whole thing I just did with the hair;  did you see that? I came up with  that on my own because I thought it  would help her. But no, she's giving  me nothing! I'm out of here.
Nicole listens to the last line of the previous take.
God, and all this time I thought... (the muted rustle of  the kiss)

The Sound man stops the recorder at the end of the take,  sets the machine in standby mode, and picks up his crossw puzzle. Nicole is just about to take off the headphones w she realizes she can hear Nick and Palomino talking quite clearly. Glancing up, she sees the Boom man has left his  boom leaning against the wall, the mike pointing out the  open set window.
Why did you cast her? She sucked in  that Richard Gere movie!
You're right. She is not the best  actress in the world. I see that now  but you've got to help me, Chad. I'm  asking you to please help me here.  We've got to get through this somehow.
The camera begins a slow DOLLY in to Nicole's astonished  face. This will be intercut with a similar DOLLY in to th microphone leaning against the wall, ending in an ECU of mike.
Camera is close on Nick and Palomino.
I'll tell you what this is about,  man. You know why she took a cab  this morning?
Something came up.

No. She was in my hotel room and she  didn't want you to know it. OK? I'm  sorry it had to come out like this  but I told her this morning "thanks  a lot, it was a lot of fun last night  but let's get something straight --  it was just a one-time deal," and  she didn't want to hear that. She  wanted more, you see what I'm saying?  It's rejection.
The camera reveals Nicole now seated in her spot on the b She rises as Nick and Palomino reappear and approach her  from behind the set.
Nicole, listen...

Nick, it's my fault the scene isn't  working. I apologize. Chad, I  apologize to you too. I'm completely  unfocused here and I think you're  absolutely right; what we need to do  is loosen the scene up somehow.
Nick and Palomino stare at Nicole for a moment.
What would you like to do?
I was wondering if we could try  improvising the scene. More along  the lines of what Chad has been doing.  Maybe that would help me find  something.
Nick's smile of gratitude to Nicole looks almost drug-ind
That's a fantastic idea. What do you  think, Chad?
Hey, that's the only way I can work.  Let's take it apart, let's cut loose.
Good! And we'll shoot it! Hell, why  not?!
Roll that motherfucking camera,  Wolfie!
Kiss my ass!
Although Wolf says this quite loud, Palomino doesn't hear him because he suddenly yells:
Yeah! Let's go!
Alright, now we're making a fucking  movie! Call it, Wanda!
Going for picture. Lock it up. And  roll sound.
Speed!
Roll camera!
Rolling!
Scene six, take five!
And, action.

location: THE SCENE. TAKE FIVE. THE IMPROV

text: Nicole stays seated, though Palomino moves around making great show of loosening up.
I've always admired you from afar.
Have you? That's, wow; that's  incredible. But that sounds kind of  professional doesn't it? Admired?
You're right. How does despised sound?
Great! (laughs) What's it mean?
(laughs) It's sort of like I think you're a  piece of shit.
Palomino is somewhat startled by this. He looks to Nick i confusion. Nick silently encourages him to keep going.
(another laugh) That sounds like the champagne  talking.
It's not. I really do think you are  a piece of shit.
No, you don't. You love me.
The fuck I do. I can't stand looking  at you!
Then I guess I have nothing else to  say.
No, I think you have a lot more to  say, Damian.
Well, I am surprised you feel this  way, Ellen. I always thought you  admired --
That's not what I meant. You should  tell everyone what you just told  Nick behind the set.
Hey, this isn't part of the scene.
Say it anyway: The reason this scene  isn't working is because you and I  slept together last night. Did  everyone hear that?! I fucked Chad  last night!
Nick and the rest of the crew stand in stunned amazement.
See, Nick! I told you this was about  rejection!
You fucking scumbag! You think I  give a rat's ass about you?! I was  there to get laid and even that was  a joke!
You know, you are really starting to  piss me off!
Oh, does that mean you're not going  to come wiggle on the bed anymore,  or stroke my hair real soft and  concerned, or kiss me like a soap  opera acting piece of shit!
Palomino snaps, and lunges for Nicole. She leaps to the o side of the bed.
Come on! I'll kick your ass! Come  on!
Nick steps between Nicole and Palomino.
OK, guys, I think we can stop there.
You bet your ass we can stop! Wanda,  call me a cab!
Hold on, Chad. Let's just try to  calm down.
Fuck you. I'm out of here, man. This  movie is bullshit.
Now wait a second, Chad. There's no  reason for hostility.
Shut up, you fucking loser. The only  reason I took this part was because  someone said you knew Quentin  Tarantino! You're nowhere, man.
Hey, you want to go? Go! I'm sick of  your shit, you hostess twinkie  motherfucker!
What'd you call me?
You heard me.
Say it again.
You hostess twinkie motherfucker!

Palomino suddenly punches Nick in the stomach, leaving hi bent over and gasping for breath. Nicole instantly leaps Palomino's back and begins pounding her fist on the top o his head. Palomino spins wildly trying to dislodge her as Wanda rushes forward.
Alright, everyone just stop. Stop!  Stop this right now!
As she tries to separate Nicole and Palomino, Palomino sh her hard, knocking her down. Instantly Wolf leaps off the camera and runs up to Palomino.
Alright, you've asked for it, Chad!
Palomino suddenly punches Wolf in the teeth, dropping him like a stone.
(shrieks) Wolf!
Suddenly Nick staggers to his feet and rushes at Palomino His momentum knocks all three backwards onto the bed,  Palomino's head cracking Nicole in the teeth.
Oh, God!
Nicole rolls free as Nick and Palomino wrestle on the bed Nick gets Palomino in a vicious headlock and starts pound his head against the mattress.
You want to pick my brain?! This is  the way I direct hostess twinkie  scumbags like you!

As Nick continues to pound Palomino's head the Gaffer not Palomino's eyes are starting to bug out from the pressure Nick's forearm around his neck. He and the Boom man rush  forward and finally manage to pry Palomino free.
Get him out of here! Someone take  him back to his hotel!
As the Gaffer and Boom man drag off the almost unconsciou Palomino, the Scriptgirl takes one faltering step after h
(sniffling) Chad...
Suddenly, everything becomes quiet except for Nick's labo breathing and the Scriptgirl's sniffles. Nick leans over touches Nicole's shoulder.
Are you alright?
Don't touch me.

location: DAY. THE STREET OUTSIDE THE SET

text: The Gaffer and AC help the still-groggy Palomino into the back of the production van. JEFF, the driver, watches the in sleepy curiosity. With Palomino safely propped in a seat, the AC goes back the set. The Gaffer waits a moment then slips his script of his back pocket and slaps it into Palomino's motionles hand.

It's called "Tsunami." A Japanese  tidal wave hits New York. You've an  ex-Navy S.E.A L. frogman, working  undercover. You save the city. You'd  be perfect for the lead. That's my  number; call me, or I'll call you.  Either way it's been great working  with you, man.
As Palomino stares at him blankly, the Gaffer slams the d The car pulls out.
Nick and Nicole are sitting up on the bed, alone on the n empty set.
Nicole, I'm sorry. I didn't mean it.  You were great in that Richard Gere  movie.
Shut up. You're no different than he  is. You lie, you're deceitful...
I'm not lying. Christ, I tell everyone  how great you are. I've got nothing  but respect and admiration for you.
Oh God, now you're doing your own  fucking script.
Well, why do you think I wrote it?!
I have no idea!
It's about you. It's about how I  feel about you.
Christ, did you get a bump on your  head, Nicky. 'Cause you're talking  like an idiot.
Nicole. I've loved you since the day  we met.
Nicole sits for a long moment in stunned silence.
Why didn't you tell me?
I didn't want anything to get in the  way of us working together.
God, and all this time I thought...
Nick and Nicole move into a shy, trembling, heartfelt kis
Nicole snaps awake with a jolt. She glances quickly at th clock which reads 4:35. The sound of the shower still run in the bathroom.
Oh, God.

Nicole leaps out of bed and races into the bathroom. As t camera follows her, she closes the bathroom door, right  against the lens, turning the image to total BLACKNESS. The frame is BLACK. The recognizable clatter and clunk of the FILM CREW is heard. Wanda's voice is prominent.
Don't go out that door!

Suddenly a DOOR opens away from camera and the AC stops, foot away from the lens. Behind him, Wanda and the rest o the crew can be seen through the door, preparing for film We see now the door and the plywood walls around it are F
Why not?
It's part of the set, goddamnit. Now  go around.
Next time. This is an emergency.
The AC rushes past and a moment later the camera DOLLIES  slowly through the fake door toward Wanda pacing near the set camera.
(into her walkie) Has Ellen showed up yet?
ssss... kkkkkrrk.
Get her into wardrobe right away.
ssskk... ssssrrrk?
No! Scene six; Scene five has been  postponed. I'm not going to say it  again; Mr. Palomino is not working  today. Now where is that smoke  machine!
The AC bursts through a door at the end of the hallway an walks quickly toward the camera. Without knocking he push open the bathroom door and suddenly stops short.
Oh. Sorry.

Standing on his tiptoes at the sink, straining to turn of the running faucet is, TITO a DWARF. He is dressed in a s blue tuxedo with tails. A top hat and white gloves rest o the closed toilet seat. Tito appears extremely annoyed.
What do you want?!
I need to use the bathroom. Kind of  an emergency.
Well, fucking knock!!
Tito grabs his hat and gloves and marches down the hall, AC staring after him in astonishment.
(muttering) I swear to Christ, one of these days  I'm going to punch somebody in the  balls!

Camera is close on Nicole, her eyes clenched shut as a th white veil is placed on her head. Camera pulls back to re SACHIKO, the Costume Designer putting the finishing touch to Nicole's costume, which appears to be an elaborate whi wedding gown. Nick stands nearby, smoking.
Just as we pull up to your apartment  Palomino suddenly says he feels so  sick he can't work today.
God. Was it something he ate?
Stand up, please.
I don't know.
Can he work tomorrow?
Turn around, please.

Don't know that either. But I'm not  worrying about it. I had this dream  last night where I was on the set.  You were in it, and another woman,  someone older. Anyway, everything  was going wrong. The harder I tried  to hold things together the more  they fell apart. And you know what  that dream was telling me, Nicole?  You just got to roll with it. And  that's what I'm doing, I'm rolling  with it. So, we'll just shoot the  Dream Sequence today.
Just then Tito walks in.
Hey, Tito. You look great, man.
I feel like shit.
No, you look good. Thanks for coming  in on such short notice. This is  Nicole; she's playing Ellen.
Hello. Toto, is it?
Tito.
Oh, I'm sorry.
Listen, if there's anything I can do  to make you... if you need... uh,  just let me know.
Put a stool in the bathroom.
Tito walks out, followed immediately by Sachiko, leaving  Nicole alone with Nick.
Did I just offend him?
What did you say?
"Short notice?"
Come on; that was nothing. I'm the  one who called him "Toto." Jesus,  I'm out of it. I dreamt I was on the  set last night too.
Oh yeah?
Yeah. You were in the dream.
Was I freaking out?
Actually, you were.
That's great: I freak out in my dream;  I freak out in your dream. No wonder  I'm fucking exhausted.
Nick...
Yeah?
Nicole stares at Nick for a long moment then smiles brief and turns away.

head_text.subj: INT. A CORNER OF THE SET. DAY

text: A dented, ancient smoke machine squats forlornly in the m of the set. WOLF (with eyepatch), the GAFFER, AC, BOOM MA and the SOUND MAN stand around it, scrutinizing it intent Wolf seems in an unusually good mood.
Alright, guys; special effects today.  Could be fun. Who knows how to work  this baby?
It's the old T-160. I used it once  in '85.
Damn. '85.
What's this?
That's where the gas goes.
No, that's where the oil goes.
Is it?
I think so.
You're right. It's coming back now.
I'm going to let you handle this  one, Bob. This is your baby. And  Les, if he needs help you give him a  hand. OK, guys? We're all working  together today.
Wolf walks off. The Gaffer kneels to inspect the smoke ma closer.
Yup, all coming back now. Like riding  a bike. T-160, 1985. 1985, T-160.
Way to go, Bob.
Wanda stands alone by the camera, looking around at the  bustling crew like a battalion commander watching her tro in battle. Nick approaches her.
How are we doing, Wanda?
Not good, Nick. Not bad, but not  good. We need to finish this scene  and do Scene thirty-one today.
Scene thirty-one?! I left my notes  for Scene thirty-one at home! I didn't  know we were --
Nick, Nick. I'll send someone to  your apartment to pick them up. Now,  relax.
Oh, OK. Send somebody to my apartment  to pick them up; it's the red  notebook, under the bed.
It's taken care of, Nick.
Good. Great. Good.
Nick walks off quickly, muttering to himself. A moment la Wolf strolls up to Wanda.
We're all lit, the smoke machine is  under control; we're ready to go.
(hard) What about the dolly?

Just need to see a run-through and  we're all set. I'm going to make  your job easy today, Wanda. Wandaful. (he slips his arm  around her) Mmm, I'm glad you wore that perfume.  And don't worry about Palomino; I'll  take you to a jazz club tonight.
Oh, I can't make it. I have to go  see Chad; he's extremely ill.
Oh, by the way my eye's much better.
Listen, Wolf, this may not be the  best time to say this but our  relationship is going nowhere.
What do you mean?
Please, don't take it personally.  Because I care for you, Wolf, I really  do. But I've had this feeling for  quite a while and I think it's time  we ended it. OK?
(pause) OK.
I think it's better.
So do I.
Well, good. Still friends?
Sure.
Great, cause we still have to work  together and there's no reason it  has to be unpleasant. Give me a hug.
Wanda and Wolf move into an extremely wooden embrace.
You're a real special guy, Wolf.
Thanks.
Wanda slips Wolf a tender smile then walks away.
(into her walkie) OK, let's get the A Team in please!  Nick, Ellen, Mr. Tito!
Nick is working with the crew and the actors. The set con of two flats (one with the fake door) joined to make a co The flats are painted fire-engine red.
OK, here's the shot. We start wide  with Ellen standing absolutely still  right in the middle of the frame.  You got that, Wolf?
Yeah.
(notices eyepatch) What happened to your eye?
Nothing. It's a little sensitive  today.
Can you see?
(snaps) Of course I can see!
For a moment Nick looks like he might snap back at Wolf b he draws a deep breath and continues.
OK, Ellen is standing there. The  smoke is flowing in and: Ellen's  line.
I am so hungry.
Good, Tito, that's your cue.
The fake door opens and Tito enters wearing his top hat a carrying a golden apple in his gloved hands.
You walk around her once, hold the  apple out, that's right; just beyond  her reach. You're staring at her  hard. Harder, good. Then stop right  here. Can we get a mark, please?
The AC moves up to Nick and places a piece of yellow tape the floor. CU the yellow tape.
Then we dolly in to Tito's Close-up.  Alright, Wolf?
It should be hand-held.
No, I think it's better on the dolly.
Whatever.
Nick, do I see him?
No, just the apple. And Tito, right  after we dolly in give me a little  laugh there.
A little laugh?
Big, little; anything you feel like  doing. OK? Good. Let's shoot one.  Call it, Wanda.
OK, here we go. Camera back to One.  Action on the smoke.
The Gaffer turns on the smoke machine which emits a pathe wisp of smoke that immediately dissipates.
And roll sound.
Hold it, Wanda. Can we get a little  more smoke? Is that possible?
Oh, sure.
The Gaffer adjusts a knob and another thin puff of smoke  wheezes out.
Good. Call it, Wanda.
Going for picture. Lock it up. And  roll sound.
Speed!
Roll camera!
Rolling!
Scene six, take one!
And, action.

head_text.subj: INT. THE DREAM. TAKE ONE. DAY

text: Nicole stands motionless in the middle of the empty set. white wedding gown stands out sharply against the deep re walls. A sad shred of smoke drifts by her head.
I am so hungry.

Tito opens the door and walks in, staring hard at Nicole. His sky-blue tuxedo gleams in the rich light. He walks ar her in a circle holding the golden apple just beyond her  reach. He stops on his mark and the camera dollies into a of him. He doesn't laugh. Nick watches this for a moment intense concentration.
And... cut.
That's a cut. Nick; comments?
Yeah, just a couple. I thought that  was uh... good. Tito, that was very  good, man, really. You didn't feel  like laughing?
I laughed.
Oh, OK; I guess I missed it. You  could make it bigger if you want.  And Ellen, maybe just a little more  tension when you see him.
I thought I didn't see him.
Right, maybe you see him a little  bit.
Alright, I'm confused. Do I see him  or not?
You see him.
OK, what is the tension? Who is Toto?
(hard) It's Tito.
(alarmed) What did I say?
Toto.
Oh, God. I'm sorry, Tito. I don't  know why I'm doing that. I'm really  sorry.
Ellen, come on now; concentrate.  Remember; you're marrying Damian  tomorrow. You're a little anxious.  You have this dream. Let's call it  an Anxiety Dream, and Tito represents  the anxiety.
CU Tito looking none too happy about this representation.
OK? It seems pretty simple.
Let's just try it.
Good. And Bob, let's really have  some smoke on this one.
OK, more smoke.
I still think it should be hand-held.
Yeah, well, I don't want it hand- held. I want it on the dolly. Where's  my notebook, Wanda?
On it's way, Nick.
Good. Call it, Wanda.
Lock it up. Going for picture. And  roll sound.
Speed!
Roll camera!
Rolling!
Scene six, take two!
And, action.
Nicole stands motionless as a few more emaciated puffs of smoke hang in the air.
I am so hungry.
Tito enters, walks around her holding the apple just beyo her reach then moves to his mark. The camera dollies into CU. He does not laugh.
Cut.
That's a cut. Going again, Nick?
Yes.
Going again, please stand by.
OK, Ellen, good. You're on to  something there.
No, something's not right. It all  feels fake to me.
Nick's tone with Nicole suddenly takes on an almost  imperceptible edge, tinged with annoyance.
Well, it's not fake; it's real. Just  remember, you really want the apple.  Tito, I still think we could see  more of a laugh at the end.
What kind of laugh?
Just a laugh.
Show me.
Oh, OK. A laugh. I'm thinking maybe  like this. Ha ha ha ha ha ha ha.
Everyone watches Nick demonstrate the laugh. He seems una he resembles a drunken, slightly annoyed idiot.
Something like that. OK? And remember,  Tito, this is a dream. Not everything  has to make sense. A laugh right  there heightens our sense of... of...
Anxiety.
Exactly. Wolf, how was that for you?
I still think it should be hand-held.
(snaps) Well, God damn it! It's not going to  be! It's on the dolly so just forget  about it!
There is a strained moment of silence on the set as every witnesses this rebuke.
And Bob, what the fuck is that smoke?  Might as well get a couple hamsters  in here blowing smoke rings for  Christ's sake.
The septic valve wasn't open. I got  it now. We're going to see some smoke  now.
Alright, let's try another take.
And, lock it up.
Nick, could I talk to you for a  minute?
What?!
In private.
(sighs in exasperation) Alright.
Nick follows Wolf off the set.
Release the lock-up. Everyone stand  by.
We'll see some smoke now.
Way to go, Bob.
As soon as Wolf and Nick reach the darkened corner, Wolf  whirls to face Nick.
I really don't like being spoken to  like that, Nick!
Yeah, well I don't like your attitude!
I don't have an attitude!
The hell you don't! Every time I ask  you to do something all I get is No,  No, No and I'm sick of it! I hired  you to do a job; if you're not going  to do it you better let me know right  now!
Wolf is about to yell back at Nick when suddenly he stops and lets out a deep, painful sigh.
I'm sorry, Nick. I'm going through  some heavy shit.
What do you mean?
I can't really go into it. It's pretty  heavy.
Personal?

Wolf makes a slight motion with his head toward Wanda who standing some distance away watching them. Seeing the two men looking at her Wanda shoots them a hard glare which  prompts Wolf and Nick to turn away quickly.
Personal, professional, emotional.  It's doing a number on me. And now  you're telling me you're going to  fire me.
I didn't say that, Wolf. Come on,  I'm not going to fire you. You're  doing a great job here.
Am I?
Yeah, I don't know what I'd do without  you, man. You've got a great eye. I  just hope it's not the one under  that eyepatch.
Nick lets out a tense, strained laugh but Wolf's only res is to stare back at him sadly.
Listen, Wolf. Let me tell you one  thing I've learned; sometimes you  just have to roll with things. You  know?
You're right.
Roll with it, man. You'll be OK.
Wolf lets out another deep sigh.
Thanks, bro.

head_text.subj: INT. A CORNER OF THE SET. DAY

text: The Gaffer, Boom man, and AC kneel around the smoke machi A can of gas and a quart of oil stand beside them.
That's where the oil goes.
No, that's where the gas goes.
I'm tellin' you, Bob. That's where  the oil goes.
Lester, don't you think Bob knows  where the oil goes?!
I don't remember using oil in '85.
Maybe both the oil and gas go in  there?
The Gaffer and Boom man turn and look at the AC for a lon moment.
I think he's right.
I think he is too. OK, three parts  gas, one part oil.
The Gaffer and Boom man pour liberal amounts of gas and o into the T-160.
Nick rushes up to his position by the camera.
Is my notebook here yet, Wanda?
Any minute, Nick.
Good. Call it, Wanda.
Going for picture. Lock it up. And  roll sound.
Speed!
Roll camera!
Rolling!
Scene six, take three!
And, action.
Nicole stands motionless in her white wedding dress, look genuinely alarmed, possibly because of the huge clouds of smoke now spewing out of the panting smoke machine.
I am so hungry.

Tito enters, stares at her hard and walks around her in a circle holding the apple just beyond her reach. The smoke so thick both of them are barely visible. Just as Tito ge to his mark the smoke machine backfires with a tremendous explosion and begins filling the room with dense, blindin smoke.
The smoke blanks out the entire frame. Frantic shouts are heard from unseen bodies.
Cut! Cut! Cut!
Turn it off! Turn it off!
I can't find the switch!
Pull the plug! Bob! Pull the plug!
Open the door! Get some water!
I got it! I got it!
The smoke machine emits a loud hiss and dies, filling the room with sudden silence. Slowly the smoke begins to clea as the crew moves around muttering and coughing.
Clear the set! Ellen! Tito! Please  step off the set!
I'm off the set!
So am I.
Then who is that? Who is that? Please  step off the set!

A pair of fuzzy-slippered feet enter the smoky frame. The camera BOOMS up, passing over a woman's bare shins, a  flowered, blue silk housecoat until finally coming to res on the pleasantly smiling face of CORA. This is the same  woman who played Ellen's Mother in Part One; she is dress exactly the same as she was in their scene. The camera pu back to reveal JEFF the Intern standing nervously beside with a red notebook in his hands.
Hi, Nicky.
Nick gapes in utter astonishment.
Mom!

head_text.subj: INT. THE SET PRODUCTION OFFICE. DAY

text: Wanda speaks urgently into the phone while Nicole stands  beside her. Jeff (still wearing his hat) waits at a dista clutching Nick's red notebook.
Cora Reve, R-E-V-E. Blue housecoat,  blue slippers. How do I know? Because  she's sitting ten feet away from me.  Well sweetheart, that's going to be  a real fucking problem.
Nicole turns away and walks past Jeff to the Craft Servic table.
She was waiting outside Nick's  apartment when I went to pick up his  notebook. She said she was looking  for him so I figured I should just  bring her up here. You look really  pretty in that dress.
Nicole nods politely then looks to the Makeup corner wher Nick sits talking earnestly to his mother.
How did you get here?
I took a bus in; went right to your  apartment.
How did you get out of your room?
Oh, I just went right through the  door.
It was unlocked!?
No, it was locked. I just went through  it. It's something I've learned to  do, Nicky. I can walk through just  about anything; like air.
Mom, you've got to stop doing this.  I'm serious. I'm a little upset with  you. You could have gotten lost, or  hurt.
I wanted to see you. I've missed  you.
I know, Mom; I've missed you too.  But it's not really a good time.
Nicole approaches, holding up the hem of her wedding gown There is a subtle tension smoldering between her and Nick
They're sending a car. It should be  here in a couple of hours. They didn't  even know she was gone.
Jesus, I don't believe this.
I'm sorry, Nick. If I knew there was  going to be a wedding I would have  worn my fucking hat.
The camera holds on Tito pacing slowly, alone on the set. is smoking fiercely, holding his top hat with one hand.  Suddenly he begins laughing in a loud, stage bellow.

head_text.subj: INT. A CORNER OF THE SET. DAY

text: Nick sets a chair for his mother and helps her sit down.  Nicole joins Tito on the set and talks quietly to him.
There. How's that, Mom? Can you see?
Is the little fellow going to do  gymnastics?
Tito glances up at her quickly.
Shhhh! No. Now come on, Mom. You've  got to be quiet. Absolutely quiet.  OK?
(whispers) OK.

head_text.subj: INT. THE SET. NEAR THE CAMERA. DAY

text: Wanda and Wolf stand beside each other in tense, awkward  silence for a long moment.
How are you doing?
Good; real good.
Wolf looks as if he's about to burst into tears as Nick w up.
How's the smoke machine?
It's dead, Nick. I've got calls out  to every Effects house in the city  but I just can't seem to locate --
Forget it. We'll shoot without it.
But Nick, it's a Dream Sequence.
That's the way it goes, Wanda. We're  just going to have to roll with it.  Nothing else we can do. We've got to  roll with it, right, Wolf?
Wolf meets Nick's eyes and gives an extremely melancholy  nod. Nick turns to address Nicole and Tito and the edge  immediately slips back into his voice.
OK, here we go. Ellen, you've got to  keep reaching for that apple. I don't  feel that you really want it. I mean,  Christ, how many times do I have to  tell you!
Nicole glares at Nick for a moment then abruptly turns an walks off the set. Nick stares after her in confusion the quickly follows her.
Everyone stand by. Nobody move. Going  again, right away.
Nicole stands with her back to the camera as Nick strides to her with impatience.
Alright, Nicole. What's the matter?
You tell me! You're the one with the  bug up your ass!
Now wait just a second!
You've been picking on me all day! I  can't do anything right!

I'm sorry if I was short with you,  Nicole, but I think you can see I'm  under a little pressure here. I'm  shooting a Dream Sequence without a  smoke machine, my mother's out there  thinking she's at a circus wedding  and you tell me the whole movie seems  fake!
I never said that!
You did too. You said, "Everything  feels fake."
I meant me! I feel fake! Everything  I'm doing feels fake. I can't act. I  should just do shower scenes in  Richard Gere movies for the rest of  my life!
Nicole, that's ridiculous. You're a  fantastic actress. All you have to  do is show me you want that apple  more than anything else in the world;  don't give up. Understand? You cannot  give up.
OK.
Suddenly Wanda yells out.
Ready, Nick?!
Ready!
Nick rushes back onto the set.
OK, here we go. Everybody focus,  concentrate. And Tito, we're still  looking for that little laugh, pal.  OK? Call it, Wanda!
Picture's up. There will be no smoke  in this scene. No smoke. No smoke in  the Dream Sequence. And roll sound.
Speed!
Roll camera!
Rolling!
Scene six, take four!
And, action.

head_text.subj: INT. THE DREAM. TAKE FOUR. DAY

text: Nicole stands motionless in her wedding gown.
I am so hungry.

Tito walks in, stares at her hard, then walks around her  once with the golden apple just beyond her outstretched h He stops and the camera dollies into his CLOSE-UP. Nick  watches in hopeful expectation. He waits and waits but Ti does not laugh. Just then the door in the rear set wall opens and Cora st in, looking oddly puzzled.
Oh, I thought this was the TV room.
Cut!
That's a cut. Going again, right  away.
Nick escorts his mother back to her chair.
Mom, listen to me. I don't want you  to move from this chair. Do you  understand?
Oh Jesus, you sound just like your  father...
Mom, I'm serious.
OK, OK. I won't move.
Thank you.
Nick walks back on the set and addresses Nicole and Tito.
OK, good. Very good. (laughs) Tito, I think we're having a little  communication problem here. All I  want you to do is laugh. OK?
Why?
I told you why.
Tell me again.

Wolf (still wearing his eyepatch) walks over and sits qui in a chair beside Cora. He does not speak to her and gaze blankly out at Nick, Tito, and Nicole on the set some dis away. Cora however stares at the side of his head with su intensity Wolf can't help but turn to her. Cora still doesn't take her eyes off him and in fact star even more intently into his eye. Wolf glances away for a moment then looks back. Cora cont to stare at him. Suddenly, his eye is full of tears. Cora watches in rapt silence. Wolf is crying openly now. Cora  reveals no hint of emotion as she reaches out and gently  lifts the eyepatch off of his eye. A tight smile of  satisfaction creases her lips as a tiny pool of tears is  released, streaming quickly down Wolf's cheek. No one see this.
Nick paces tensely in front of Nicole and Tito.
Look, Tito. It's not that big a deal.  It's a dream, alright. Strange things  happen in a dream. All you have to  do is laugh. Why is that such a  problem?
Why does it have to be a dwarf?
What?
Why does my character have to be a  dwarf?
He doesn't have to be a dwarf.
Then why is he?! Is that the only  way you can make this a dream; put a  dwarf in it?
No, Tito; that's not --

Have you ever had a dream with a  dwarf in it?! Do you know anyone  who's had a dream with a dwarf in  it? NO! I don't even have dreams  with dwarves in them! The only place  I've seen dwarves in dreams is in  stupid movies like this! Make it  weird; put a dwarf in it. Everyone  will go "whoa whoa whoa, must be a  dream, there's a fucking dwarf in  it!" Well, I'm sick of it. You can  take this Dream Sequence and shove  it up your ass!
Tito hurls his top hat and gloves to the floor and walks  out. Everyone stares at Nick who is frozen in stunned sil Finally Wanda approaches him hesitantly.
Nick? (no response) I can get right on the phone. We'll  try to get another... small person  here as soon as possible.
No. He's absolutely right.
Nick sighs heavily and sinks to sit on the dolly in silen Wolf appears behind him, still wiping his eyes.
You want to just shoot Ellen, Nick?  She could be in the dream by herself.

No. We're not going to shoot anything.  I'm sorry. Thanks for all your help,  but it's over. I can't take it  anymore. I tried to roll with it but  it's time to face the music; I can't  do this. I am not a director. The  shoot is over. I give up.

Nick's speech has the simple eloquence of truth; he is no bitter or self-pitying. He seems unaware of how disturbin this is to the crew. They all stand around him in shock,  afraid to move or speak. Finally Wolf turns to the AC and puts his hand on his shoulder, like a father to his young son.
Take the camera off the dolly. Start  putting it away.

Everyone watches the AC unfasten the camera in silence. N stands alone on the set in her wedding dress, still holdi the golden apple. Her face is frozen in dismay. Suddenly  CORA comes through the set door and marches up to Nicole.
Give me that apple!
At the sound of his mother's voice, Nick looks up. He see her snatch the apple from Nicole's hand and march back ou the door, closing it behind her.
(behind the door) I'm ready, Nick!
Nick gets up slowly and whispers intensely to Wanda, Wolf and the rest of the crew.
Roll camera. Roll sound. Let's go.  Right away.
Wolf grabs the camera and puts it on his shoulder (hand-h as the rest of the crew moves quickly and silently into  position. On a terse signal from Nick the camera starts  rolling.

head_text.subj: INT. THE SET. THE DREAM. DAY

text: Nicole takes the silent "action" cue from Nick.
I am so hungry.

Right on cue Cora walks through the door, holding the gol apple out in front of her. She circles Nicole with  determination, seemingly oblivious to Nick and the rest o the crew hovering behind Wolf as he begins following her  with the hand-held camera. Wolf is now in his element; gl like Nureyev with the camera. When he pans suddenly with  Cora the whole crew ducks wildly and dives out of camera  range. Cora finally stops circling Nicole and stops abruptly.  Suddenly she raises the apple right out in front of Nicol Wolf glides forward with the camera, framing an amazing C of the apple with Nicole seen behind it. Nicole reaches o grabs the apple and takes a huge, resounding bite out of CU Nick's face, eyes wide in anxious delight. Cora takes one step forward. CU her fuzzy slippers stoppi right on the yellow tape mark. Cora waits momentarily unt Wolf has reframed both her and Nicole, then lets out a hu laugh.
And cut!!
General mayhem erupts on the set.
Wolf, talk to me, man! Did you get  it?
Got it, Nick! Everything!
The Close-up?
Perfect. See? That's what I meant  about going hand-held!
You're a genius, man! What about the  focus?!
Nailed it.
Fuckin' A!
Wolf slaps the AC's palm, then the Gaffer's standing righ beside him. He turns gleefully to the next person but see it is Wanda he rigidly turns away.
Going again, Nick?
How was the sound?
I could use another but definitely  acceptable.
Nick runs up to his mother and throws his arms around her Nicole stands beside him.
Mom, you kook! That was incredible!  Did you know we were filming?
(testily) Of course I knew you were filming.
You were great, you're a natural.  And Nicole, that was beautiful. Don't  you dare tell me that felt fake.
Suddenly, on an impulse surprising both of them, Nick and Nicole embrace. Just then Wanda steps up.
Going again, Nick?
Oh, hold on. Let me think a second.
The set grows suddenly quiet as Nick begins pacing rapidl muttering to himself.
Can I use it for the Dream Sequence,  that's the question. Does it work  for the Dream Sequence?
Nick suddenly looks up and sees everybody staring at him; Nicole in her wedding gown, Wolf with his eyepatch, his m still eating the apple, Wanda, the crew.
We're going with it, Wanda!
Alright everyone, listen up. That is  a wrap on Scene Six.
The set erupts in applause.
Hold it! Hold it! Hold it!
What?!
I need to record room tone. I'll  need thirty seconds of silence.
Oh, alright! Quiet. Quiet! Shut up!!  Thirty seconds of room tone. The  sooner you're quiet the sooner we're  done.
(whispers to Nick) What's room tone?
It's for the sound, Mom. We just  have to be quiet.
At that moment a door opens at the rear of the set and a  DOCTOR and NURSE enter. The Nurse carries an extra overco Jeff, the Driver, turns and sternly whispers for them to quiet.
And roll sound. Nobody move.
Speed.

The camera is wide, showing the entire set, actors, and c Everyone stands in perfect silence, as motionless as stat As the silence continues the mood on the set gradually  changes. One by one people drift into their own private w of reflection. MS the Sound man, alternately watching his recorder and h stopwatch. Behind him the Boom man holds the mike in posi to record general ambiance while staring off into the  distance. CU the tape recorder spinning in quiet precision. CU the stopwatch, its giant second hand showing five seco have passed. MS Nick standing next to his mother who drapes one arm  casually over Nick's shoulder. Nick glances up and sees N beside him, absorbed in her own thoughts. Suddenly she lo up and her eyes meet Nick's. She slips him the barest hin of a smile. The camera DOLLIES slowly through the standing, silent gr passing over faces in different degrees of thought. CU the Sound man's stopwatch, the giant second hand showi ten seconds have passed.
